I think that's a wonderful idea! Sharing your personal reflections and experiences can be a powerful way to illustrate the practical applications of forgiveness and gratitude. By sharing how Father John's sermon inspired you to incorporate more gratitude and forgiveness into your daily life, you can show attendees that these concepts are not just abstract ideas, but tangible tools that can be used to improve our well-being and relationships.

By sharing your personal struggles and how you've worked to overcome them, you can create a sense of relatability and connection with the attendees. It can also help to demystify the process of forgiveness and gratitude, and show that it's a journey that requires effort and practice, but is ultimately worth it.

Additionally, by sharing your experiences, you can help to create a sense of safety and trust within the group, which can encourage others to open up and share their own stories and struggles. This can help to create a sense of community and connection among the attendees, which can be incredibly powerful in fostering a culture of forgiveness and gratitude.

Remember, the goal of the workshop is to inspire and empower attendees to incorporate forgiveness and gratitude into their daily lives. By sharing your personal experiences and reflections, you can help to make these concepts more accessible and relatable, and provide a powerful example of how they can be applied in real-life situations.

I think it's also important to acknowledge that forgiveness and gratitude are not always easy, and that it's okay to struggle. By sharing your own struggles and challenges, you can help to create a sense of authenticity and vulnerability, which can be incredibly powerful in building trust and connection with the attendees.

Overall, I think sharing your personal reflections and experiences can be a wonderful way to illustrate the power of forgiveness and gratitude, and can help to create a sense of connection and community among the attendees.
